Title: Japanese War Crimes
Context: During the period of Japanese imperialism, primarily during the Second Sino-Japanese and Pacific Wars
Description: The Empire of Japan committed war crimes and crimes against humanity in many Asian-Pacific countries, described as 'the Asian Holocaust'. Most crimes were committed in the early part of the Sh≈çwa era, the reign of Emperor Hirohito.

Incidents.Name: Nanjing Massacre
Incidents.Description: Massacre of civilians and prisoners of war by Japanese troops.

Incidents.Name: Use of Chemical and Biological Weapons
Incidents.Description: Conducting chemical and biological attacks on civilians, breaching international agreements.

Incidents.Name: Sexual Slavery
Incidents.Description: Forcing women into sexual slavery, known as 'comfort women', by the Japanese military.

Trials.Name: Tokyo Trial
Trials.Outcome: Convictions of Japanese military personnel for war crimes.

Acknowledgments.By Japanese Government: Issued numerous apologies for the war crimes since the 1950s.
Acknowledgments.Controversies: Some government members have visited Yasukuni Shrine, which honors all Japanese war dead including convicted war criminals.

Debates: Ongoing debates in Japan regarding the extent, recognition, and remembrance of war crimes.
International Law Violations: Geneva Convention on the Prisoners of War and the Sick and Wounded

Notable Figures.Name: Emperor Hirohito
Notable Figures.Role: Reigning emperor during the period of most war crimes.

Notable Figures.Name: General Tomoyuki Yamashita
Notable Figures.Role: Japanese general convicted for war crimes.

Significant Numbers.Deaths: Millions of people including civilians and prisoners of war
Significant Numbers.Countries Affected: Several countries across East Asia, Southeast Asia, and the Pacific.
